HI! Thanks for being here to test StudyBuddy


the platform is still in an embryonic phase and constantly evolving, your support and feedback is necessary to build the application in the best way and help as many students as possible.

INTRO

At the bottom of the page you can see a ticking timer represented by a green snake.

The goal is to get to the end of the study session, in the middle of which you have breaks (apples) that you can take at any time.

THE BREAK

By default they last 5 minutes. Short breaks are used to get some air, eat an apple and rest your eyes, while remaining concentrated and unconsciously re-elaborating what you have studied up to that moment.


We advise you not to indulge in the distractions of social media and the like and to make the most of these well-deserved 5 minutes. Instead, take a walk to the bathroom or drink some water.

The break can be stopped at any time.

MOTIVATION

tracking study and break time has multiple pros:


  • mental clarity between study and break moments
  • awareness of how you managed time
  • resistance to distractions (telephone etc...) during the study phase

The timer was designed to follow the famous Pomodoro Technique:


A study session lasts 2 hours divided between concentrated study and small breaks:


25 min studio

5 min break


repeat this 4 times


At the end, a long break: this is the real break where you can finally go back to scrolling (if absolutely necessary) or take a walk and come back more energized than before.


You can also change the settings if you want to follow different timings.


If you want to learn more about this technique, click on the link.

We noticed, interviewing several people, that the Pomodoro technique has some limitations, including:

  • 25 minutes is too little for many people
  • confusing
  • there are those who prefer to do 1 hour in a row (or more)
  • you don't want to interrupt the exercise/chapter halfway to take a break

For this reason we created the flexible pomodoro, with the aim of trying to resolve these critical issues.

Now we think about study sessions u>: a session normally lasts two hours and has 3 breaks of 5 minutes in between (same intervals as the classic pomodoro). own needs.

Yet to be implemented, it is an option for all those who want to study without the time constraints imposed by previous techniques.


The objective is therefore to to have an account of how much time it actually took to study compared to the breaks, possibly comparing it with your expectations.

The ToDo list can be shown using the + button at the bottom right of the screen.


There are two types of Todos:

  • Deadline: they have a deadline and are in the left column
  • Without Date: in the right column, by default, you can add a date at any time and move it between the deadlines


Those with deadlines appear in the calendar on the home page.


Once marked as 'done ' will be moved to the "done" list.

tasks.name: a normal task can become a deadline
tasks.notes: just click on it, open this mirror (which I would make in another color) and after adding a date click on the move to deadline button

tasks.name: and ends up in a different column

postIts.content: The way the post-its work is also very simple: just add them from the + at the bottom right.

Clicking on the palette you can change the color.

Clicking on the X deletes the post-it.

using keyboard shortcuts you can also format the text:


  • with - creates a bulleted list
  • bold (ctrl or cmd + b)
  • italics (ctrl or cmd + i)
  • underline u> (ctrl or cmd + u)
There is the possibility of adding all the links that may be useful. Also in this case just press the + at the bottom right.

In the calendar on the home page you can add an event by clicking the point where you would like to add it.



You can then change the title, start time, duration, color and add notes related to the event.



You can also drag the event vertically to move it within the same day and lengthen it to change its duration.
